author: By Alex Traub
title: Timuel Black, Strategist and Organizer for Black Chicago, Dies at 102
description: He assembled attendees of the March on Washington, mentored a young Barack Obama and wielded the solidarity of the South Side as a tool for political power.
content: Timuel Black, who mobilized the political power of the predominantly Black South Side of Chicago, taught others — including a young Barack Obama — how to do the same, and in his final decades compiled oral histories giving voice to his community’s Black working class, died on Wednesday at his home on the South Side. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Gang suspected in kidnapping of missionaries is among the country’s most dangerous.
description: The gang, called 400 Mawozo, captured several clergy members in April, and the local authorities say it is behind Saturday’s kidnapping.
content: The gang that the police say kidnapped 17 missionaries and their family members in Haiti on Saturday is among the country’s most dangerous and one of the first to engage in mass kidnappings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisians Recall Revolution Reluctantly, if at All: ‘It Just Faded Away’
description: When a monument to those killed in the 2011 uprising was recently damaged, few took notice or even cared in a town, and country, where there is now more regret than a wish to remember.
content: LE KRAM, Tunisia — When part of one of Tunisia’s only monuments to its 2011 revolution disappeared earlier this year, not many noticed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Jaguars Beat Dolphins to Snap N.F.L.’s Longest Losing Streak
description: Jacksonville Coach Urban Meyer and rookie quarterback won their first game as pros on a 53-yard field goal as time expired, ending the team’s 20-game losing streak.
content: LONDON (AP) — The Jacksonville Jaguars ended their 20-game losing streak when Matthew Wright kicked a 53-yard field goal as time expired in a 23-20 victory over the Miami Dolphins on Sunday in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: With Walk-Off Win, Atlanta Snags an Early Edge Over Dodgers
description: Austin Riley’s ninth inning single pushed Atlanta to victory over Los Angeles in Game 1 of the N.L.C.S. — just like his homer did in last year’s Game 1.
content: ATLANTA — The Los Angeles Dodgers reached the National League Championship Series with a final, bitterly contested pitch on Thursday night in San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s Plans Raise Questions About What U.S. Can Afford Not to Do
description: Democrats are debating whether doing nothing will cost more than doing something to deal with climate change, education, child care, prescription drugs and more.
content: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers debate how much to spend on President Biden’s sprawling domestic agenda, they are really arguing about a seemingly simple issue: affordability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Ng
title: Bringing Attention to the Maori Language, One Song at a Time
description: “Waiata/Anthems,” Lorde’s “Te Ao Marama” EP and a host of other projects are aimed at revitalizing the Indigenous language of New Zealand via music.
content: In August, Lorde released her third album, “Solar Power.” Three weeks later, she put out an EP called “Te Ao Marama,” with five songs from the record translated into Maori, the Indigenous language of New Zealand. The second release was no mere afterthought — it was part of longtime conversations in her native country about boosting a language that not long ago experts feared could die out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Celia McGee
title: Elizabeth Diller Is Retelling Edmund de Waal’s Story — and Her Own
description: Designing a show at the Jewish Museum in New York has illuminated corners of hidden history in her life, the architect says. “Edmund dug into his past. I didn’t. I couldn’t bear it.”
content: In Edmund de Waal’s home in South London stands a 19th-century vitrine once in the Victoria & Albert Museum. Bronze and mahogany, seven feet tall, it was purchased by the British author and ceramic artist to hold a fabled collection of miniature carved netsuke figurines from Japan passed down over four generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: As Trump Thunders About Last Election, Republicans Worry About the Next One
description: Donald Trump is the Republicans’ greatest asset in mobilizing voters. But some fret that his obsession with false claims about the 2020 election could cost the G.O.P. in 2022.
content: Republicans believe they have a good shot at taking Congress next year. But there’s a catch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: For Uber and Lyft, the Rideshare Bubble Bursts
description: Rideharing companies made a lot of promises. They’re not being kept.
content: Piece by piece, the mythology around ridesharing is falling apart. Uber and Lyft promised ubiquitous self-driving cars as soon as this year. They promised an end to private car ownership. They promised to reduce congestion in the largest cities. They promised consistently affordable rides. They promised to boost public transit use. They promised profitable business models. They promised a surfeit of well-paying jobs. Heck, they even promised flying cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Washington Hears Echoes of the ’50s and Worries: Is This a Cold War With China?
description: Incursions into Taiwan’s air zone, a space launch and what looked like a prisoner swap raise a question that is about more than just semantics. It could signal a dangerous new mind-set.
content: When Kevin Rudd, the former Australian prime minister and longtime China expert, told a German newsmagazine recently that a Cold War between Beijing and Washington was “probable and not just possible,” his remarks rocketed around the White House, where officials have gone to some lengths to squelch such comparisons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Ruth Graham
title: Missionaries With an American Christian Group Kidnapped in Haiti
description: Up to 17 missionaries and their family members were taken by gang members in the capital of a country where kidnappings have become increasingly common.
content: Seventeen people, including three children, associated with an American Christian aid group were kidnapped on Saturday by a gang in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, as they were leaving an orphanage, according to a former field director for the group, Christian Aid Ministries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Gentili
title: This Is What Will Make Sex Work in New York Safer
description: Two bills are before the New York State Senate proposing to decriminalize sex work — only one truly helps the sex workers themselves.
content: When I took my first client as a sex worker in the 1980s, I had no other choice. It was right after the fall of the dictatorship in Argentina. As a young trans woman, I found that sex work was the only way for me to survive, but I faced constant harassment and violence, especially from la policía. So, I left my home to come to the United States, thinking things would be different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Anni Bergman, Therapist Who Listened to Children, Dies at 102
description: She was part of a groundbreaking study that observed how very young children separated from their mothers. Late in life, she became a photographer’s muse.
content: Anni Bergman, an Austrian-born psychoanalyst who worked with autistic children and contributed to a landmark study of early childhood development, died on Oct. 2 at home in Manhattan. She was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: John Grisham on Judges, Innocence and the Judgments He Ignores
description: The best-selling author, whose new book, “The Judge’s List,” is about a murderous member of the bench, talks about the Supreme Court, wrongful convictions and what it means to be “review-proof.”
content: John Grisham is an unapologetic master of the industrial-strength page turner. His latest, “The Judge’s List,” due out from Doubleday on Tuesday, is a sleek suspense novel about the hunt for a serial killer who is also a sitting judge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Mass Abduction of U.S. Missionaries Startles Even Kidnap-Weary Haiti
description: “Where is this country going?” Gang members seized 16 Americans and one Canadian, among them five children, as they visited an orphanage.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Children on their way to school, street vendors selling their wares, priests mid-sermon — few Haitians, rich or poor, are safe from the gangs of kidnappers that stalk their country with near impunity. But the abduction this weekend of 17 people associated with an American missionary group as they visited an orphanage shocked officials for its brazenness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: Syria Accuses Israel of Assassinating Official Near Golan Heights
description: Midhat Saleh, who oversaw the strategic Golan Heights boundary for Syria, was shot and killed by a sniper, the government said.
content: The Syrian government on Saturday accused Israel of assassinating a high-ranking Syrian official who spent 12 years in an Israeli prison on terrorism charges before serving decades in the Syrian government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: How a Stunning Lagoon in Spain Turned Into ‘Green Soup’
description: Tons of dead fish have washed ashore in recent years from the Mar Menor, a once-crystalline lagoon on the Mediterranean coast that has become choked with algae. Farm pollution is mostly blamed.
content: LA MANGA, Spain — The Mar Menor, a saltwater lagoon on the coast of southeastern Spain, was long renowned for its natural beauty, drawing tourists and retirees to its pristine warm shallows and the area’s gentle Mediterranean climate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: In the Trial of Ahmaud Arbery’s Accused Killers, Unsettling Video Will Have a Starring Role
description: Three white men are charged in the death of Arbery, an unarmed Black man, in a coastal Georgia suburb. Jury selection begins on Monday.
content: ATLANTA — The three white Georgia men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery have already come in for harsh judgment from the highest of places. Donald Trump called the slaying of Mr. Arbery, an unarmed Black man, “disturbing.” Barack Obama described it as an example of enduring racial injustice. Brian Kemp, Georgia’s Republican governor, called it “absolutely horrific.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Booster Shots, Climate Change, NASA: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Roblox, the Gaming Site, Wants to Grow Up Without Sacrificing Child Safety
description: The company, which went public earlier this year, has lessons for other internet outfits aiming to attract younger users even as its own audience gets older.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — As Dave Baszucki, the chief executive of the gaming company Roblox, took the stage at a conference hosted by his company on Thursday, he reflected on how much had changed for Roblox since its last in-person event two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: A Brilliant Realization
description: Freddie Cheng mixes up a neat Monday puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — I’ve said it before, and I’m certain I’ll say it again — I love hearing the origin stories of crossword themes. I deeply enjoy gaining a little insight into a constructor’s “aha moment,” where something totally mundane, in the right person’s hands, transforms into a remarkable bit of wordplay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Red Sox Power Up, Again and Again, to Even Series With Astros
description: Grand slams in consecutive innings set the tone in a game that dragged on past four hours but was never in doubt.
content: HOUSTON — Since late last season, whenever a Boston Red Sox player smashes a home run, he plops down afterward in a metal laundry cart and gets pushed the length of the cramped dugout through a receiving line of high fives. It’s a silly but unique ritual, and the players all seem to love it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames and Taylor Glascock
title: Chicago Sky Beat Phoenix Mercury for First W.N.B.A. Championship
description: The Sky battled back from a second-half deficit to beat the Mercury in a thriller. They were unlikely champions after a .500 record during the regular season.
content: CHICAGO — At the final buzzer, Candace Parker sprinted down the court in triumph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 18, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Takes on the N.F.L.’s Jon Gruden Scandal
description: An episode hosted by Rami Malek also featured appearances from his “No Time to Die” co-star Daniel Craig.
content: You know an N.F.L. scandal has wide-reaching implications when it makes it as far as a “Saturday Night Live” opening sketch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Fake Polls and Tabloid Coverage on Demand: The Dark Side of Sebastian Kurz
description: The downfall of Austria’s onetime political Wunderkind put a spotlight on the cozy, sometimes corrupt, relationship between right-wing populists and parts of the news media.
content: VIENNA — It seemed like a miracle. For years, Austria’s conservative party had languished far behind its rivals. Then in May 2017, the polls spectacularly reversed, giving the conservatives newfound credibility that helped them convince voters that they had a real chance of winning. Five months later, in elections, they did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood’s Behind-the-Scenes Workers Reach Deal, Averting Strike
description: The tentative agreement came hours before a strike deadline and avoids a production shutdown at TV and movie studios already scrambling to make up for time lost in the pandemic.
content: LOS ANGELES — You might say that the people behind the cameras have found their voices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 17, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 17, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about the changing nature of California suburbs referred incorrectly to the architectural style of the houses in the Clairemont Villas development. They are ranch-style houses, not Craftsman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack D'Isidoro, John Woo and Sam Anderson
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Laurie Anderson Has a Message for Us Humans’
description: For half a century, she has taken the things we know best — our bodies, our rituals, our nation — and shown us how strange they really are.
content: When the Hirshhorn Museum told Laurie Anderson that it wanted to put on a big, lavish retrospective of her work, she said no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Russian Film Crew Wraps Space Station Shoot and Returns to Earth
description: A Russian actress and film director landed near Russia’s spaceflight base in Kazakhstan after 12 days in orbit.
content: A Russian actress and a film director landed safely on Earth early Sunday after spending 12 days aboard the International Space Station shooting scenes for the first feature-length drama made with scenes shot in space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: Sphinx Virtuosi Bring an Intriguing Vision to Carnegie Hall
description: An ensemble of 18 string players who are Black and Latino set a reflective and spirited tone on Friday, with solos by the charismatic bass-baritone Davóne Tines.
content: “Tracing Visions” was the intriguing title of the program Sphinx Virtuosi, an ensemble of 18 top-notch string players who are Black and Latino, presented at Carnegie Hall on Friday. As Afa S. Dworkin, the president of Sphinx, explained in comments to the audience, that phrase spoke both to the organization’s mission and the music played so impressively on this night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Bondita Baruah
title: Amid Flames and Gunfire, They Were Evicted From Where They Called Home
description: Critics say an Indian state’s campaign to expel longtime residents on government land marks the ruling party’s latest campaign against Muslims.
content: DHOLPUR, India — Ahmad Ali watched helplessly as the police set his home on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Last Chance to Save American Democracy
description: This season of oppression is very likely the beginning of an era of oppression — unless Congress intervenes.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, has indicated that he plans to schedule a vote for Wednesday to open debate on a new voting rights bill, the Freedom to Vote Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Sister Megan Rice, Fierce Critic of U.S. Nuclear Arsenal, Dies at 91
description: Arrested more than 40 times, she was best known for her role in the 2012 break-in at the Oak Ridge nuclear complex in Tennessee.
content: Sister Megan Rice, a Roman Catholic nun who was arrested more than 40 times for protesting America’s military industrial complex, most spectacularly for breaking into one of the world’s largest uranium storage sites, died on Oct. 10 at the residence of her religious order in Rosemont, Pa. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Haitian gang kidnaps missionaries.
content: A gang in Haiti’s capital kidnapped a group of 17 people associated with an American aid group, including five children, according to local authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: In Newcastle, Songs Drown Out the Hard Questions
description: As long-suffering fans cheered the arrival of Saudi riches at their club, talk of the new owners’ plans and the current team’s flaws took the day off.
content: NEWCASTLE, England — In the shadow of St. James’s Park, a man in a flowing white thobe was standing on a chair outside Shearer’s bar, conducting a swaying choir. It cycled through all the newest numbers in Newcastle United’s songbook: the one about being richer than Manchester City, the one questioning the identity of Paris St.-Germain, the one that just goes: “Saudi Mags.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Despite a Punishing Drought, San Diego Has Water. It Wasn’t Easy.
description: Sustainability measures that the city and county have taken over decades are paying off. But residents still might have to do more.
content: LAKESIDE, Calif. — In many parts of California, reminders abound that the American West is running out of water. “Bathtub rings” mark the shrinking of the state’s biggest reservoirs to some of their lowest recorded levels. Fields lie fallow, as farmers grapple with an uncertain future. A bed-and-breakfast owner spends $5 whenever a tourist showers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Nearly $7 Million Awarded in First Earthshot Prizes
description: Costa Rica and the city of Milan were among the five winners that each received one million pounds, or nearly $1.4 million, to continue sustainability and conservation efforts during a ceremony in London.
content: LONDON — Costa Rica and the city of Milan on Sunday were among the first to be awarded one million pounds, or nearly $1.4 million, for their sustainability and conservation efforts as part of a newly established environmental prize presided over by Prince William and Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: Boston Found a Top Reliever in the Yankees System. Blame Instagram.
description: Garrett Whitlock was rehabbing from elbow surgery when the Red Sox saw his videos on social media. Getting him for a pittance from a rival was icing on the cake.
content: The Jeep Wrangler with the Yankees tire cover became a familiar sight at the Central Alabama Baseball Academy in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Nets Had a Chance to Win Over New York. Now, They’ll Try Again.
description: Viewed by some as gentrifiers, the Nets finally may have the starpower to win a championship and loosen the grip the city’s other N.B.A. team has on the region.
content: Right after the final buzzer sounded on Game 7 between the Milwaukee Bucks and the Nets during the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference semifinals last spring, Giovannie Cruz had to leave his house in Elizabeth, N.J., and go to a nearby park. Cruz, an avowed Nets fan for most of his 39 years, had watched the game with his 4-year-old son and “acted like a lunatic” until the end, when the Nets lost in heartbreaking fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Fauci urges police officers to get vaccinated.
description: Police should see vaccination as the best way to protect themselves on the job, Fauci says.
content: Police officers and others responsible for public safety should view vaccination against Covid-19 as a key part of their role, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease doctor, said during an interview on Fox News Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Moity
title: Taking the Times Crossword Out for a Test Solve
description: A meticulous team reviews the crossword, vetting each clue and answer because “there is no such thing as a neutral word.”
content: As a crossword puzzle tester for The New York Times, one of Evie Eysenburg’s jobs is to call Will Shortz, who has edited the puzzle for 28 years, and tell him when something is wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: How Top Runners Reframe Their Races
description: “Out there, you have to do whatever you can to stay positive, and I did stay positive the whole time,” Sara Hall said after placing third in the Chicago Marathon. “That was a win in itself.”
content: Call it the great reframing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Lead-Tainted Water Flows in Another Michigan City
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 17, 2021.
content: “If I had a magic wand, I would solve every problem that’s plaguing the city of Benton Harbor as we speak. However, government doesn’t work that way. The city of Benton Harbor is a creature of the state, and the state is a creature of the federal government.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Erin Schaff
title: As Manchin Blocks Climate Plan, His State Can’t Hold Back Floods
description: As the senator thwarts Democrats’ major push to reduce warming, new data shows West Virginia is more exposed to worsening floods than anywhere else in the country.
content: FARMINGTON, W.Va. — In Senator Joe Manchin’s hometown, a flood-prone hamlet of about 200 homes that hugs a curve on a shallow creek, the rain is getting worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: South Korea Reconsiders a Rite of Manhood: The Draft
description: Military conscription has become less popular. The rules have loosened. But experts still worry about the threat from the North.
content: SEOUL — Kim Hyeongsu performed poorly on his rifle qualification test for the South Korean Army, to the point where he was berated for squandering the government’s bullets. An officer ordered him to do a plank while yelling repeatedly, “I am a tax waster!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: As a Woman Was Raped, Train Riders Failed to Intervene, Police Say
description: The SEPTA train car near Philadelphia had several passengers aboard but none called 911 while the woman was sexually assaulted, the authorities said.
content: As a woman was being raped while on a train near Philadelphia on Wednesday night, riders watched, failed to intervene and did not call 911, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Bill Clinton Is Released From Hospital
description: The former president was admitted to a California hospital on Tuesday for treatment of an infection that developed into sepsis, officials said.
content: Former President Bill Clinton was released from a California hospital on Sunday after being admitted on Tuesday for treatment of a urological infection that developed into sepsis, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 6 in the N.F.L.
description: Lamar Jackson can lead the Ravens to any kind of win, the Jaguars made the most of the Dolphins’ gaffes and Aaron Rodgers did Aaron Rodgers things against the Bears.
content: One month ago, the Baltimore Ravens were in a state of Code Red.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Will New Covid Treatments Be as Elusive for Poor Countries as Vaccines?
description: Merck has taken a step to make its antiviral pill available in poor nations, but many obstacles remain for broad access to coronavirus drugs.
content: Nearly a year after the first Covid-19 vaccination campaigns began, the vast majority of the shots have gone to people in wealthy nations, with no clear path toward resolving the disparity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon and Diante Lee
title: Are the Giants Watchable Yet?
description: *Grimace*
content: Time is a flat circle, but we want to help you break it. To that end, we’ve enlisted two experts — one familiar with the ins and outs of New York’s football teams, the other a nationally focused football analyst — to answer an essential question as a weekly service to readers: Is this team good yet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: Town Rattled by Bow-and-Arrow Killings Ponders Terrorism and Mental Illness
description: The police in Norway, initially pointing to Islamic extremism, now say an attacker was “not well, mentally.”
content: KONGSBERG, Norway — A few years ago, a nervous Danish man walked into a mosque in this placid Scandinavian town, seeking help in delivering a message to the world that he claimed to have received “from above.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: What I Believe About Life After Death
description: Death, for all of us, is a journey interrupted.
content: My friend Thomas died in August. His death was sudden and tragic. He and his 22-year-old child were killed in a car accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Across the U.S., clashes intensify between city officials and the police over vaccination issues.
description: Officers in many departments have been slow to get vaccinated and to report their vaccination status, and city officials are struggling to make them pick up the pace.
content: In many cities across the country, there is friction between governments and law enforcement unions over requirements that officers get vaccinated against the coronavirus or prove their vaccination status, leading to contentious public clashes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
title: Police Search for Motive in British Lawmaker’s Killing
description: An attack has rekindled questions about the security of members of Parliament.
content: LONDON — The police searched for answers on Sunday about what might have motivated a 25-year-old British man of Somali heritage, the suspect in the brutal slaying of a Conservative Party lawmaker during a meeting with his constituents that has shaken Britain’s political establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Workers Flex Their Muscles
description: The governor of Texas bans vaccine mandates. Prices are rising quickly. And WeWork is finally going public.
content: More employees quit their jobs in August than in any month in the last two decades, the Labor Department reported on Tuesday. As many businesses struggle to hire, the surge in quitting is one of several signs that workers have more leverage in the labor market. Average hourly wages have also climbed in recent months, especially for low-paying jobs. Thousands of workers at the agriculture equipment maker Deere & Company went on strike on Thursday after overwhelmingly rejecting a contract proposal worked out with the company by negotiators for the United Automobile Workers union. And Hollywood production workers reached a tentative agreement on Saturday for a new three-year contract with film and television studios after threatening to walk off the job if the studios did not meet demands for higher pay, strengthened requirements for meal breaks and other concessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: What is Christian Aid Ministries and what does it do in Haiti?
description: The group, based in Ohio, distributes food and clothing, funds schools, teaches farming methods and helps with emergency relief.
content: Christian Aid Ministries, the charity whose workers were kidnapped in Haiti on Saturday, has a long history of working in the Caribbean nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: At Axel Springer, Politico’s New Owner, Allegations of Sex, Lies and a Secret Payment
description: A high-flying German media giant is ahead on digital media but seems stuck in the past when it comes to the workplace and deal-making.
content: A high-level editor at the powerful German tabloid Bild was trying to break things off with a woman who was a junior employee at the paper. He was 36. She was 25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Buckley
title: Ciao, Alitalia
description: A satirical goodbye is bid to Alitalia, airline to the popes.
content: Alitalia may have had its faults, but how many airlines can claim to have been the “pope’s airline” for over five centuries?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: As Some Black Staff Members Leave Congress, Those Who Remain Call for Change
description: Low pay, a high cost of living and an insulated culture make it hard for Black aides to build a career in Congress.
content: When Chanda Jefferson, a science teacher from Columbia, S.C., got the opportunity to work on Capitol Hill, she was thrilled to use her classroom experience to help shape education policy. She also hoped that when her fellowship was over, she could expose her students at home to a different, exciting career path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: In This Postseason, Pitching Six Innings Feels Like a Lot
description: Atlanta’s Max Fried has recorded 18 outs in each of his last two starts, standing out in an era of openers, quick hooks and mustachioed middle men.
content: ATLANTA — There are 38 metal flags running up and down the light poles above right field at Truist Park, saluting standout seasons for the home team. A dozen flags signify titles won before the modern World Series, which seems like résumé padding for the franchise now known as the Atlanta Braves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My Waitress Had Also Been Told That She Would Soon Be Laid Off’
description: A Waldorf regular looks back, an iced coffee in a precarious spot and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Democrats Should Sell Themselves to Avoid Electoral Disaster
